author: schone_wizard
content:
<@!425572898787426305> how would a validator provide a beneficiary address to which the transaction fees get credited to? wouldn't those fees belong in the consensus layer's validator rewards world?
(sorry if this is a stupid question, but that note in the rewards section stood out for me)

author: benjaminion
content: The beneficiary address would be the Coinbase of the block (as it is now) - a normal Ethereum address. Transaction fees do not get credited to the validator's balance on the beacon chain.

author: m.kalinin
content: Right, the default option is to re-use `coinbase` CLI parameter of existing mainnet clients and have it in execution clients. The more advanced approach might be to pass the `coinbase` via consensus API to allow this address to be send by consensus client.

author: schone_wizard
content: Ah… so theoretically if a validator is chosen to propose the next block. They’d fetch the execution payload along with the coinbase specified there from their own execution layer client running locally?

author: schone_wizard
content: And the transaction fees would get credited to an address they own that way?

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> Yes, the block proposer gets to dictate the construction of the execution layer payload (evm activity) and thus specifies where any execution layer profit goes (via the coinbase most frequently/easily, but also any side channel payments or mev otherwise)
